solution_line_template: Removing the time of the train ride from the journey shows that his trip to get on the train took him {total_trip_hours} hours – {train_ride_hours} hours = <<{total_trip_hours}-{train_ride_hours}={pre_train_hours}>>{pre_train_hours} hours.

Converting this time into minutes shows that getting to the train took {pre_train_hours} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes/hour = <<{pre_train_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}={pre_train_minutes}>>{pre_train_minutes} minutes.
Waiting for the train to arrive took twice as long as his walk, so {walk_minutes} minutes * {wait_multiplier} = <<{walk_minutes}*{wait_multiplier}={wait_minutes}>>{wait_minutes} minutes.

This means that his bus ride must have taken {pre_train_minutes} minutes – {wait_minutes} minutes - {walk_minutes} minutes = <<{pre_train_minutes}-{wait_minutes}-{walk_minutes}={bus_minutes}>>{bus_minutes} minutes.
